prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA because I want my hair fixed, for free, by the hairdresser?
[What I showed her](http://imgur.com/KmuiLRL)


[What I got](http://imgur.com/gEiWAi4)


I asked my stylist to do a light brown rose gold, and emphasized that I wanted it a light brown, warm color.

I showed her the picture more than a week in advance of the appointment so she had time to get any colors she didn’t have. 

I told her multiple times I wanted a light brown.  I know you can’t perfectly match the picture, but I think I made it obvious I wanted more brown than red in my hair.  I would have been fine without the rose tint.  My hair was bleach blonde to begin with.

She’s going to try to fix it but I don’t think I should have to pay, this is clearly not what I asked for.  Am I the asshole?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. So, the situation is that they went to a hairdresser and wanted a specific color, light brown with a warm rose gold tone. They showed a picture a week in advance, emphasized they wanted more brown than red, and now the result is something else. They don't want to pay for the fix.

First, the hairdresser's job is to follow the client's instructions. The user provided a reference image and clearly stated their preferences. They also mentioned multiple times their desired color. If the hairdresser didn't have the right color and needed to mix, maybe they should have informed the client beforehand. Or maybe the client's instructions weren't clear enough. But the user said they made it obvious they wanted more brown than red. The problem is the hairdresser might have misunderstood or didn't check if the mixed color was right. Since they had the picture in advance, they should have been prepared. The client isn't at fault for not getting the right color, especially if they communicated clearly. The hairdresser is responsible for the outcome. So the user not wanting to pay for the fix makes sense. They aren't in the wrong. Answer B.
